aslsd.homogeneous_poisson package

Submodules

aslsd.homogeneous_poisson.hom_poisson module

class aslsd.homogeneous_poisson.hom_poisson.HomPoisson(d, index_from_one=False, mu_names=None, is_fitted=False, fitted_mu=None, fit_residuals=None)

Bases: object

Class for homogeneous Poisson models of point processes.

Let \(\mathbf{N}\) be a d-dimensional counting process with conditional intensity \(\boldsymbol{\lambda}\). We say that \(\mathbf{N}\) is a homogeneous Poisson process if there exists positive constants \((\mu_{i})_{i \in[d]}\) (that we call baselines), such that for all \(i \in[d]\) and for all \(t \geq 0\), we have

\[\lambda_{i}(t):=\mu_{i}.\]
d

Dimension of the homogeneous Poisson process.

Type

int

index_from_one

Start the indexing of baselines from 1 instead of 0. The default is False.

Type

bool, optional

mu_names

List of names of baseline parameters. The default is None.

Type

list of str, optional

is_fitted

True if this model has been fitted. The default is False.

Type

bool, optional

fitted_mu

Array of fitted baselines. The default is None.

Type

numpy.ndarray, optional

fit_residuals

List of fit residuals. The default is None.

Type

list of numpy.ndarray, optional

clear_fit()
fit(list_times, T_f, clear=True, write=True)

Fit the Homoegeneous Poisson model to some observations.

We suppose that we observe a path of a d-dimensional counting process \(\mathbf{N}\) started at time \(0\) up to some terminal time \(T\).

The least squares error (LSE) of this model for these observations is defined as

\[\mathcal{R}_{T}(\boldsymbol{\mu}):=\frac{1}{T} \sum_{k=1}^{d} \int_{0}^{T} \lambda_{k}(t)^{2} \mathrm{~d} t-\frac{2}{T} \sum_{k=1}^{d} \sum_{m=1}^{N_{T}^{k}} \lambda_{k}\left(t_{m}^{k}\right).\]

For a homogeneous Poisson model, this simplifies to

\[\mathcal{R}_{T}(\boldsymbol{\mu}):=\sum_{k=1}^{d} \bigg( \mu_{k}^{2} -2 \frac{N_{T}^{k}}{T} \bigg).\]

This expression is minimized if for all \(k \in [d]\) we have

\[\mu_k^{*}:=\frac{N_{T}^{k}}{T}.\]

The optimal baseline vector \(\boldsymbol{\mu^{*}}\) defined above is also the maximizer of the loglikelihood of these observations.

Parameters

  • list_times (list of numpy.ndarray) – List of jump times for each dimension.

  • T_f (float) – Terminal time.

  • write (bool, optional) – Save the results. The default is True.

Returns

fitted_mu – Fitted baselines.

Return type

numpy.ndarray

get_param_names(index_from_one=False)

Get the standard names of baseline variables.

By default, we denote the baselines by \((\mu_{i})_{i \in[d]}\).

Parameters

index_from_one (bool, optional) – Start the indexing of baselines from 1 instead of 0. The default is False.

Returns

mu_names – List of names of baseline parameters.

Return type

list of str

get_residuals(list_times, mu=None, write=True)

Compute the residuals of the model.

We suppose that we observe a path of a d-dimensional counting process \(\mathbf{N}\) started at time \(0\) up to some terminal time \(T\).

The residuals of a homogeneous Poisson model \(\boldsymbol{\mu}\) are defined by

\[\left\{\mu_k(t^k_{m+1}-t^k_{m}): k \in [d], m \in [N^k_T-1] \right\}.\]
Parameters

  • list_times (list of numpy.ndarray) – List of jump times per dimension.

  • mu (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Vector of baselines. If None, use the fitted baselines. The default is None.

  • write (bool, optional) – Save the results. The default is True.

Raises

ValueError – Raise an error if the baseline is not specified and there is no fitted baseline saved as an atrribute.

Returns

residuals – List of residuals per dimension.

Return type

list of numpy.ndarray

simulate(T_f, mu=None, seed=1234)

Simulate a path of the homogeneous Poisson model.

Parameters

  • T_f (float) – Terminal time.

  • mu (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Vector of baselines. If None, use the fitted baselines. The default is None.

  • seed (int, optional) – Seed of the random generator. The default is 1234.

Raises

ValueError – Raise an error if the baseline is not specified and there is no fitted baseline saved as an atrribute.

Returns

list_times – List of jump times per dimension.

Return type

list of numpy.ndarray
